author: Виктория Маркова
title: Профессор Пустынский рассказал, что у более 60% людей рак полости рта выявляется на поздних стадиях
text:
Профессор Пустынский рассказал, что у более 60% людей рак полости рта выявляется на поздних стадиях
Рак слизистой оболочки полости рта — опасное заболевание с высоким риском рецидивов и смертности. Более 60% пациентов диагностируются на поздних стадиях, поэтому ранняя диагностика имеет критическое значение. По словам профессора кафедры онкологии и лучевой терапии Института хирургии, доктора медицинских наук Ильи Пустынского, своевременная диагностика позволяет добиться высоких показателей излечения, написал Life.ru.
Злокачественные опухоли могут поражать различные отделы полости рта. В начале заболевания появляются безболезненные узелки, уплотнения или поверхностные язвы, которые не поддаются лечению.
Симптомы, такие как жжение или покалывание во рту во время еды, должны насторожить. Если симптомы не проходят после двух недель консервативного лечения, специалист рекомендует обратиться к онкологу для детального обследования.
При ранней диагностике рак полости рта можно излечить более чем в 90% случаев. Однако на поздних стадиях пятилетняя выживаемость пациентов снижается до 23–42%.
Пустынский также выделил факторы, способствующие развитию рака полости рта: курение, злоупотребление алкоголем, недостаточная гигиена полости рта, хронические заболевания и предопухолевые состояния.

author: Shauna Foley
title: Racism still rife but NAIDOC Week a time for positivity, say elders, as they look to the future with hope - ABC News
text:
WARNING: This story contains racist and offensive language.
Bigambul and Gomeroi woman Debra Fernando always looks forward to NAIDOC Week, and says this year's theme, 'Keep the fire burning! Blak, loud and proud', is more important than ever.
"We've got to keep sharing our knowledge, and [NAIDOC] is the space to do that," she said.
"To be blak, loud and proud — to have no shame."
Ms Fernando says she remains hopeful for the future, despite experiencing racism firsthand in the days after the Voice to Parliament referendum's 'no' result last year.
"I was sitting in my office when these young kids come past yelling out, 'There's that coon that lives there'," she said.
"I thought, gosh, is this a reflection of the referendum result and the conversations they're around?
"It made me realise there could be another generation filled with hate."
Support for Indigenous Australians Aboriginal & Torres Strait Islander crisis support line 13YARN on 13 92 76 eSafety Commission's First Nations resources Ms Fernando lives in the Riverina, in southern New South Wales, where 75 per cent of the local electorate voted 'no' in last year's referendum.
She felt her heart "drop and shatter" when the results were released.
"It felt like hopelessness," she said.
"I was sceptical if Australia had grown up; clearly it hasn't."
Debra Fernando says she's still hopeful there will be a change in attitude. ( ABC News Graphics )
But Ms Fernando believes that sharing First Nations stories this NAIDOC Week can help to shape positive attitudes within the non-Indigenous community.
"I would like to see change in my lifetime," she said.
"To see that shift in Australia when everyone becomes equal."
'We are resilient' Gamilaroi woman Marjorie Anderson says many people faced similar derogatory comments during the referendum debate.
13YARN national program manager Marjorie Anderson, left, with colleagues Nikita Ridgeway and Jia Natty. ( Supplied )
Ms Anderson, the national program manager for 13-YARN, says her team saw the drastic toll negative attitudes towards Indigenous people took on communities nationwide.
"Our calls went through the roof," she said.
"The toxicity of the debate was incredibly damaging to Aboriginal people.
"It was almost like non-Aboriginal people felt like it was OK to be racist."
Ms Anderson said the helpline's crisis services had a 40 per cent rise in demand in the months before and after the Voice to Parliament referendum.
There was a 40 per cent surge in calls to the 13YARN helpline around the Voice to Parliament referendum. ( ABC News: Danielle Bonica )
But she thinks that despite the aftermath of the 'no' result, the debate was good for one thing.
"It gave [the nation] a better understanding of the cultural load for blakfellas," she said.
Ms Anderson says this has led to some progress in attitudes towards Indigenous employees.
"We see it in non-Aboriginal workplaces, where they take the initiative to ensure First Nations people feel supported," she said.
Aunty Dulcie's trailblazing career A complaint about a policeman ended Dulcie Flower's stint in a hospital emergency department. But it sparked a long career focused on improving the health outcomes of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people.
Read more
She echoes Ms Fernando's sentiment that this NAIDOC Week's theme inspires reflection and perseverance.
Ms Anderson says she hopes First Nations people continue to campaign, whether it be for a voice to parliament or for closing the gap initiatives.
"If Aboriginal people are anything, we are resilient," she said.
"We get knocked down over and over again, but we get back up.
"Our mob need to keep fighting for our young ones, for our future."
A time to be proud Brandon Nixon, chief executive of Coonabarabran Land Council and a Gamilaraay man, says he felt the disappointment of local First Nations people when the 'no' result was released.
Brandon Nixon says Indigenous people must share their stories so their culture remains strong. ( Supplied )
But he says his community will continue to use its voice despite the referendum result.
"We will not stop fighting for the rights of Aboriginal people and continuing to ensure that we have a say," he said.
Mr Nixon says this year's NAIDOC theme, 'Keep the fire burning,' is vital in motivating the community to move forward.
"The [theme] has allowed us to share who we are and our knowledge and ensure the local Gamilaraay culture lives on," he said.
"Coonabarabran has a rich culture, and we need to ensure that we share now so that fire keeps burning."
Brandon Nixon says the Aboriginal rangers program will be a highlight this NAIDOC Week. ( Supplied: Coonabarabran Land Council )
The Aboriginal rangers program is one of the successes the land council will celebrate this week.
The program aims to help young First Nations people learn traditional land knowledge while gaining a Certificate III in Conservation.
"They're currently going through training and meeting regularly with elders," Mr Nixon said.
"This ensures our wisdom and stories are being passed down."
Mr Nixon hopes the program can continue empowering future generations of Indigenous people and make sure their voices are heard.
Catch up on our NAIDOC Week content at the ABC Indigenous page and on ABC iView .
Editor's Note 12/07/2024: The ABC has chosen to include offensive language in this story to illustrate the racism referenced in this reporting.

author: Clarin.com - Home
title: Antonio Laje se despidió de América en medio de agradecimientos y fuertes acusaciones contra el INADI
text:
Antonio Laje se despidió este viernes de Bien de Mañana (BDA) por América, tras 10 años de estar al frente de dicho noticiero, con un extenso editorial en el que le agradeció a Daniel Vila, el dueño del canal, el apoyo recibido en esta década de trabajo. En tanto, lanzó una fuerte acusación contra el INADI.
"Hemos llegado al final del programa y de 10 años que hicimos BDA...", comenzó diciendo el conductor, quien desde febrero comenzará una nueva etapa de su carrera por LN+.
Y tras leer el mensaje de un ex compañero, agregó: "Vamos a empezar a disipar dudas: yo decido irme, el canal me propuso seguir pero creo hay ciclos que se terminan. Son 10 años, es mucho tiempo, la pasé fantástico acá y me he sentido como si fuera mi casa porque siempre trabajé con total libertad y muy cómodo".
Entonces Laje ponderó la labor de Daniel Vila, el dueño de América, y con quien los conductores y productores tienen "trato diario". "Es muy cercano el trato que manejan y yo la pasé fantástico y crecí mucho haciendo lo posible para hacer el mejor programa y darles el mejor producto", le dijo a los televidentes.
"Yo acá dije lo que pensaba y lo voy a seguir haciendo. Esto es lo que soy. Te puede gustar o no pero lo hago pensando siempre en tener un país mejor, con futuro y progreso...", continuó su relato Antonio.
Y lanzó una fuerte crítica contra el Instituto Nacional contra la Discriminación, la Xenofobia y el Racismo: "En este canal yo la pasé muy bien y tuve momentos muy complicados como por ejemplo cuando el INADI, que es un centro de operaciones políticas que por suerte se va a terminar, armaron una operación brutal, increíble y política con el único fin de sacarme del aire".
"Me hicieron un daño gigantesco, y personal, a mi familia, y a mi mujer y a mis hijos pero acá estamos y esto se lo debo exclusivamente a Daniel, quien me conoce y supo siempre lo que pasaba...", continuó agradeciendo.
"Creo que hay ciclos que conviene cerrar, empezar algo nuevo y volver a ponerle nuestra impronta a otro proyecto. Por eso me voy, no hay otra razón...", repitió Laje, quien además de periodista también trabaja como piloto de una empresa de vuelos privados.
"No es fácil irse después de mucho tiempo pero hay que seguir adelante y encarar nuevos proyectos y este va a ser uno de ellos...", adelantó sobre su llegada a LN+.
Luego, él saludó a sus compañeros y estos a él, se refirió al enorme apoyo del público del otro lado de la pantalla y al gran trabajo de cada uno de los técnicos y productores que estuvieron todos estos años a su lado.
Finalmente, el conductor volvió a agradecerle a Vila para luego cerrar diciendo: "La hemos pasado muy, muy bien. Para mí BDA es una marca única así que muchísimas gracias. Disfruten este fin de año y nos vemos pronto".
